35 class Patch(artist.Artist):
36 """
37 A patch is a 2D artist with a face color and an edge color.
38  
39 If any of *edgecolor*, *facecolor*, *linewidth*, or *antialiased*
40 are *None*, they default to their rc params setting.
41 """
42 zorder = 1
43  
44 # Whether to draw an edge by default. Set on a
45 # subclass-by-subclass basis.
46 _edge_default = False

48 def __init__(self, *,
49 edgecolor=None,
50 facecolor=None,
51 color=None,
52 linewidth=None,
53 linestyle=None,
54 antialiased=None,
55 hatch=None,
56 fill=True,
57 capstyle=None,
58 joinstyle=None,
59 **kwargs):
60 """
61 The following kwarg properties are supported
62  
63 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
64 """
65 super().__init__()
66  
67 if linestyle is None:
68 linestyle = "solid"
69 if capstyle is None:
70 capstyle = CapStyle.butt
71 if joinstyle is None:
72 joinstyle = JoinStyle.miter
73  
74 self._hatch_color = colors.to_rgba(mpl.rcParams['hatch.color'])
75 self._fill = bool(fill) # needed for set_facecolor call
76 if color is not None:
77 if edgecolor is not None or facecolor is not None:
78 _api.warn_external(
79 "Setting the 'color' property will override "
80 "the edgecolor or facecolor properties.")
81 self.set_color(color)
82 else:
83 self.set_edgecolor(edgecolor)
84 self.set_facecolor(facecolor)
85  
86 self._linewidth = 0
87 self._unscaled_dash_pattern = (0, None) # offset, dash
88 self._dash_pattern = (0, None) # offset, dash (scaled by linewidth)
89  
90 self.set_linestyle(linestyle)
91 self.set_linewidth(linewidth)
92 self.set_antialiased(antialiased)
93 self.set_hatch(hatch)
94 self.set_capstyle(capstyle)
95 self.set_joinstyle(joinstyle)
96  
97 if len(kwargs):
98 self._internal_update(kwargs)

100 def get_verts(self):
101 """
102 Return a copy of the vertices used in this patch.
103  
104 If the patch contains Bézier curves, the curves will be interpolated by
105 line segments. To access the curves as curves, use `get_path`.
106 """
107 trans = self.get_transform()
108 path = self.get_path()
109 polygons = path.to_polygons(trans)
110 if len(polygons):
111 return polygons[0]
112 return []

114 def _process_radius(self, radius):
115 if radius is not None:
116 return radius
117 if isinstance(self._picker, Number):
118 _radius = self._picker
119 else:
120 if self.get_edgecolor()[3] == 0:
121 _radius = 0
122 else:
123 _radius = self.get_linewidth()
124 return _radius
125  
126 def contains(self, mouseevent, radius=None):
127 """
128 Test whether the mouse event occurred in the patch.
129  
130 Returns
131 -------
132 (bool, empty dict)
133 """
134 if self._different_canvas(mouseevent):
135 return False, {}
136 radius = self._process_radius(radius)
137 codes = self.get_path().codes
138 if codes is not None:
139 vertices = self.get_path().vertices
140 # if the current path is concatenated by multiple sub paths.
141 # get the indexes of the starting code(MOVETO) of all sub paths
142 idxs, = np.where(codes == Path.MOVETO)
143 # Don't split before the first MOVETO.
144 idxs = idxs[1:]
145 subpaths = map(
146 Path, np.split(vertices, idxs), np.split(codes, idxs))
147 else:
148 subpaths = [self.get_path()]
149 inside = any(
150 subpath.contains_point(
151 (mouseevent.x, mouseevent.y), self.get_transform(), radius)
152 for subpath in subpaths)
153 return inside, {}
154  
155 def contains_point(self, point, radius=None):
156 """
157 Return whether the given point is inside the patch.
158  
159 Parameters
160 ----------
161 point : (float, float)
162 The point (x, y) to check, in target coordinates of
163 ``self.get_transform()``. These are display coordinates for patches
164 that are added to a figure or axes.
165 radius : float, optional
166 Additional margin on the patch in target coordinates of
167 ``self.get_transform()``. See `.Path.contains_point` for further
168 details.
169  
170 Returns
171 -------
172 bool
173  
174 Notes
175 -----
176 The proper use of this method depends on the transform of the patch.
177 Isolated patches do not have a transform. In this case, the patch
178 creation coordinates and the point coordinates match. The following
179 example checks that the center of a circle is within the circle
180  
181 >>> center = 0, 0
182 >>> c = Circle(center, radius=1)
183 >>> c.contains_point(center)
184 True
185  
186 The convention of checking against the transformed patch stems from
187 the fact that this method is predominantly used to check if display
188 coordinates (e.g. from mouse events) are within the patch. If you want
189 to do the above check with data coordinates, you have to properly
190 transform them first:
191  
192 >>> center = 0, 0
193 >>> c = Circle(center, radius=3)
194 >>> plt.gca().add_patch(c)
  • E501 Line too long (81 > 79 characters)
195 >>> transformed_interior_point = c.get_data_transform().transform((0, 2))
196 >>> c.contains_point(transformed_interior_point)
197 True
198  
199 """
200 radius = self._process_radius(radius)
201 return self.get_path().contains_point(point,
202 self.get_transform(),
203 radius)
204  
205 def contains_points(self, points, radius=None):
206 """
207 Return whether the given points are inside the patch.
208  
209 Parameters
210 ----------
211 points : (N, 2) array
212 The points to check, in target coordinates of
213 ``self.get_transform()``. These are display coordinates for patches
214 that are added to a figure or axes. Columns contain x and y values.
215 radius : float, optional
216 Additional margin on the patch in target coordinates of
217 ``self.get_transform()``. See `.Path.contains_point` for further
218 details.
219  
220 Returns
221 -------
222 length-N bool array
223  
224 Notes
225 -----
226 The proper use of this method depends on the transform of the patch.
227 See the notes on `.Patch.contains_point`.
228 """
229 radius = self._process_radius(radius)
230 return self.get_path().contains_points(points,
231 self.get_transform(),
232 radius)

234 def update_from(self, other):
235 # docstring inherited.
236 super().update_from(other)
237 # For some properties we don't need or don't want to go through the
238 # getters/setters, so we just copy them directly.
239 self._edgecolor = other._edgecolor
240 self._facecolor = other._facecolor
241 self._original_edgecolor = other._original_edgecolor
242 self._original_facecolor = other._original_facecolor
243 self._fill = other._fill
244 self._hatch = other._hatch
245 self._hatch_color = other._hatch_color
246 self._unscaled_dash_pattern = other._unscaled_dash_pattern
247 self.set_linewidth(other._linewidth) # also sets scaled dashes
248 self.set_transform(other.get_data_transform())
249 # If the transform of other needs further initialization, then it will
250 # be the case for this artist too.
251 self._transformSet = other.is_transform_set()

270 def get_patch_transform(self):
271 """
272 Return the `~.transforms.Transform` instance mapping patch coordinates
273 to data coordinates.
274  
275 For example, one may define a patch of a circle which represents a
276 radius of 5 by providing coordinates for a unit circle, and a
277 transform which scales the coordinates (the patch coordinate) by 5.
278 """
279 return transforms.IdentityTransform()

314 def _set_edgecolor(self, color):

396 def set_linestyle(self, ls):
397 """
398 Set the patch linestyle.
399  
400 ========================================== =================
401 linestyle description
402 ========================================== =================
403 ``'-'`` or ``'solid'`` solid line
404 ``'--'`` or ``'dashed'`` dashed line
405 ``'-.'`` or ``'dashdot'`` dash-dotted line
406 ``':'`` or ``'dotted'`` dotted line
407 ``'none'``, ``'None'``, ``' '``, or ``''`` draw nothing
408 ========================================== =================
409  
410 Alternatively a dash tuple of the following form can be provided::
411  
412 (offset, onoffseq)
413  
414 where ``onoffseq`` is an even length tuple of on and off ink in points.
415  
416 Parameters
417 ----------
418 ls : {'-', '--', '-.', ':', '', (offset, on-off-seq), ...}
419 The line style.
420 """
421 if ls is None:
422 ls = "solid"
423 if ls in [' ', '', 'none']:
424 ls = 'None'
425 self._linestyle = ls
426 self._unscaled_dash_pattern = mlines._get_dash_pattern(ls)
427 self._dash_pattern = mlines._scale_dashes(
428 *self._unscaled_dash_pattern, self._linewidth)
429 self.stale = True

493 def set_hatch(self, hatch):
494 r"""
495 Set the hatching pattern.
496  
497 *hatch* can be one of::
498  
499 / - diagonal hatching
500 \ - back diagonal
501 | - vertical
502 - - horizontal
503 + - crossed
504 x - crossed diagonal
505 o - small circle
506 O - large circle
507 . - dots
508 * - stars
509  
510 Letters can be combined, in which case all the specified
511 hatchings are done. If same letter repeats, it increases the
512 density of hatching of that pattern.
513  
514 Hatching is supported in the PostScript, PDF, SVG and Agg
515 backends only.
516  
517 Parameters
518 ----------
519 hatch : {'/', '\\', '|', '-', '+', 'x', 'o', 'O', '.', '*'}
520 """
521 # Use validate_hatch(list) after deprecation.
522 mhatch._validate_hatch_pattern(hatch)
523 self._hatch = hatch
524 self.stale = True
525  
526 def get_hatch(self):
527 """Return the hatching pattern."""
528 return self._hatch

530 def _draw_paths_with_artist_properties(
531 self, renderer, draw_path_args_list):
532 """
533 ``draw()`` helper factored out for sharing with `FancyArrowPatch`.
534  
535 Configure *renderer* and the associated graphics context *gc*
536 from the artist properties, then repeatedly call
537 ``renderer.draw_path(gc, *draw_path_args)`` for each tuple
538 *draw_path_args* in *draw_path_args_list*.
539 """
540  
541 renderer.open_group('patch', self.get_gid())
542 gc = renderer.new_gc()
543  
544 gc.set_foreground(self._edgecolor, isRGBA=True)
545  
546 lw = self._linewidth
547 if self._edgecolor[3] == 0 or self._linestyle == 'None':
548 lw = 0
549 gc.set_linewidth(lw)
550 gc.set_dashes(*self._dash_pattern)
551 gc.set_capstyle(self._capstyle)
552 gc.set_joinstyle(self._joinstyle)
553  
554 gc.set_antialiased(self._antialiased)
555 self._set_gc_clip(gc)
556 gc.set_url(self._url)
557 gc.set_snap(self.get_snap())
558  
559 gc.set_alpha(self._alpha)
560  
561 if self._hatch:
562 gc.set_hatch(self._hatch)
563 gc.set_hatch_color(self._hatch_color)
564  
565 if self.get_sketch_params() is not None:
566 gc.set_sketch_params(*self.get_sketch_params())
567  
568 if self.get_path_effects():
569 from matplotlib.patheffects import PathEffectRenderer
570 renderer = PathEffectRenderer(self.get_path_effects(), renderer)
571  
572 for draw_path_args in draw_path_args_list:
573 renderer.draw_path(gc, *draw_path_args)
574  
575 gc.restore()
576 renderer.close_group('patch')
577 self.stale = False
578  
579 @artist.allow_rasterization
580 def draw(self, renderer):
581 # docstring inherited
582 if not self.get_visible():
583 return
584 path = self.get_path()
585 transform = self.get_transform()
586 tpath = transform.transform_path_non_affine(path)
587 affine = transform.get_affine()
588 self._draw_paths_with_artist_properties(
589 renderer,
590 [(tpath, affine,
591 # Work around a bug in the PDF and SVG renderers, which
592 # do not draw the hatches if the facecolor is fully
593 # transparent, but do if it is None.
594 self._facecolor if self._facecolor[3] else None)])
595

598 raise NotImplementedError('Derived must override')

614 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
615 def __init__(self, patch, ox, oy, *, shade=0.7, **kwargs):
616 """
617 Create a shadow of the given *patch*.
618  
619 By default, the shadow will have the same face color as the *patch*,
620 but darkened. The darkness can be controlled by *shade*.
621  
622 Parameters
623 ----------
624 patch : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch`
625 The patch to create the shadow for.
626 ox, oy : float
627 The shift of the shadow in data coordinates, scaled by a factor
628 of dpi/72.
629 shade : float, default: 0.7
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
630 How the darkness of the shadow relates to the original color. If 1, the
  • E501 Line too long (80 > 79 characters)
631 shadow is black, if 0, the shadow has the same color as the *patch*.
632  
633 .. versionadded:: 3.8
634  
635 **kwargs
636 Properties of the shadow patch. Supported keys are:
637  
638 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
639 """
640 super().__init__()
641 self.patch = patch
642 self._ox, self._oy = ox, oy
643 self._shadow_transform = transforms.Affine2D()
644  
645 self.update_from(self.patch)
646 if not 0 <= shade <= 1:
647 raise ValueError("shade must be between 0 and 1.")
  • E501 Line too long (83 > 79 characters)
648 color = (1 - shade) * np.asarray(colors.to_rgb(self.patch.get_facecolor()))
649 self.update({'facecolor': color, 'edgecolor': color, 'alpha': 0.5,
650 # Place shadow patch directly behind the inherited patch.
651 'zorder': np.nextafter(self.patch.zorder, -np.inf),
652 **kwargs})
653  
654 def _update_transform(self, renderer):
655 ox = renderer.points_to_pixels(self._ox)
656 oy = renderer.points_to_pixels(self._oy)
657 self._shadow_transform.clear().translate(ox, oy)
658  
659 def get_path(self):
660 return self.patch.get_path()
661  
662 def get_patch_transform(self):
663 return self.patch.get_patch_transform() + self._shadow_transform
664  
665 def draw(self, renderer):
666 self._update_transform(renderer)
667 super().draw(renderer)

670 class Rectangle(Patch):
671 """
672 A rectangle defined via an anchor point *xy* and its *width* and *height*.
673  
674 The rectangle extends from ``xy[0]`` to ``xy[0] + width`` in x-direction
675 and from ``xy[1]`` to ``xy[1] + height`` in y-direction. ::
676  
677 : +------------------+
678 : | |
679 : height |
680 : | |
681 : (xy)---- width -----+
682  
683 One may picture *xy* as the bottom left corner, but which corner *xy* is
684 actually depends on the direction of the axis and the sign of *width*
685 and *height*; e.g. *xy* would be the bottom right corner if the x-axis
686 was inverted or if *width* was negative.
687 """
688  
689 def __str__(self):
690 pars = self._x0, self._y0, self._width, self._height, self.angle
691 fmt = "Rectangle(xy=(%g, %g), width=%g, height=%g, angle=%g)"
692 return fmt % pars
693  
694 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
695 def __init__(self, xy, width, height, *,
696 angle=0.0, rotation_point='xy', **kwargs):
697 """
698 Parameters
699 ----------
700 xy : (float, float)
701 The anchor point.
702 width : float
703 Rectangle width.
704 height : float
705 Rectangle height.
706 angle : float, default: 0
707 Rotation in degrees anti-clockwise about the rotation point.
708 rotation_point : {'xy', 'center', (number, number)}, default: 'xy'
709 If ``'xy'``, rotate around the anchor point. If ``'center'`` rotate
710 around the center. If 2-tuple of number, rotate around this
711 coordinate.
712  
713 Other Parameters
714 ----------------
715 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties
716 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
717 """
718 super().__init__(**kwargs)
719 self._x0 = xy[0]
720 self._y0 = xy[1]
721 self._width = width
722 self._height = height
723 self.angle = float(angle)
724 self.rotation_point = rotation_point
725 # Required for RectangleSelector with axes aspect ratio != 1
726 # The patch is defined in data coordinates and when changing the
727 # selector with square modifier and not in data coordinates, we need
728 # to correct for the aspect ratio difference between the data and
729 # display coordinate systems. Its value is typically provide by
730 # Axes._get_aspect_ratio()
731 self._aspect_ratio_correction = 1.0
732 self._convert_units() # Validate the inputs.
733  
734 def get_path(self):
735 """Return the vertices of the rectangle."""
736 return Path.unit_rectangle()
737  
738 def _convert_units(self):
739 """Convert bounds of the rectangle."""
740 x0 = self.convert_xunits(self._x0)
741 y0 = self.convert_yunits(self._y0)
742 x1 = self.convert_xunits(self._x0 + self._width)
743 y1 = self.convert_yunits(self._y0 + self._height)
744 return x0, y0, x1, y1
745  
746 def get_patch_transform(self):
747 # Note: This cannot be called until after this has been added to
748 # an Axes, otherwise unit conversion will fail. This makes it very
749 # important to call the accessor method and not directly access the
750 # transformation member variable.
751 bbox = self.get_bbox()
752 if self.rotation_point == 'center':
753 width, height = bbox.x1 - bbox.x0, bbox.y1 - bbox.y0
754 rotation_point = bbox.x0 + width / 2., bbox.y0 + height / 2.
755 elif self.rotation_point == 'xy':
756 rotation_point = bbox.x0, bbox.y0
757 else:
758 rotation_point = self.rotation_point
759 return transforms.BboxTransformTo(bbox) \
  • E127 Continuation line over-indented for visual indent
760 + transforms.Affine2D() \
  • E127 Continuation line over-indented for visual indent
761 .translate(-rotation_point[0], -rotation_point[1]) \
  • E127 Continuation line over-indented for visual indent
762 .scale(1, self._aspect_ratio_correction) \
  • E127 Continuation line over-indented for visual indent
763 .rotate_deg(self.angle) \
  • E127 Continuation line over-indented for visual indent
764 .scale(1, 1 / self._aspect_ratio_correction) \
  • E127 Continuation line over-indented for visual indent
765 .translate(*rotation_point)
766  
767 @property
768 def rotation_point(self):
769 """The rotation point of the patch."""
770 return self._rotation_point
771  
772 @rotation_point.setter
773 def rotation_point(self, value):
774 if value in ['center', 'xy'] or (
775 isinstance(value, tuple) and len(value) == 2 and
776 isinstance(value[0], Real) and isinstance(value[1], Real)
777 ):
778 self._rotation_point = value
779 else:
780 raise ValueError("`rotation_point` must be one of "
781 "{'xy', 'center', (number, number)}.")
782

964 class StepPatch(PathPatch):
965 """
966 A path patch describing a stepwise constant function.
967  
968 By default, the path is not closed and starts and stops at
969 baseline value.
970 """
971  
972 _edge_default = False
973  
974 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
975 def __init__(self, values, edges, *,
976 orientation='vertical', baseline=0, **kwargs):
977 """
978 Parameters
979 ----------
980 values : array-like
981 The step heights.
982  
983 edges : array-like
984 The edge positions, with ``len(edges) == len(vals) + 1``,
985 between which the curve takes on vals values.
986  
987 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical'
988 The direction of the steps. Vertical means that *values* are
989 along the y-axis, and edges are along the x-axis.
990  
991 baseline : float, array-like or None, default: 0
992 The bottom value of the bounding edges or when
993 ``fill=True``, position of lower edge. If *fill* is
994 True or an array is passed to *baseline*, a closed
995 path is drawn.
996  
997 **kwargs
998 `Patch` properties:
999  
1000 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1001 """
1002 self.orientation = orientation
1003 self._edges = np.asarray(edges)
1004 self._values = np.asarray(values)
1005 self._baseline = np.asarray(baseline) if baseline is not None else None
1006 self._update_path()
1007 super().__init__(self._path, **kwargs)
1008  
1009 def _update_path(self):
1010 if np.isnan(np.sum(self._edges)):
1011 raise ValueError('Nan values in "edges" are disallowed')
1012 if self._edges.size - 1 != self._values.size:
1013 raise ValueError('Size mismatch between "values" and "edges". '
1014 "Expected `len(values) + 1 == len(edges)`, but "
1015 f"`len(values) = {self._values.size}` and "
1016 f"`len(edges) = {self._edges.size}`.")
1017 # Initializing with empty arrays allows supporting empty stairs.
1018 verts, codes = [np.empty((0, 2))], [np.empty(0, dtype=Path.code_type)]
1019  
1020 _nan_mask = np.isnan(self._values)
1021 if self._baseline is not None:
1022 _nan_mask |= np.isnan(self._baseline)
1023 for idx0, idx1 in cbook.contiguous_regions(~_nan_mask):
1024 x = np.repeat(self._edges[idx0:idx1+1], 2)
1025 y = np.repeat(self._values[idx0:idx1], 2)
1026 if self._baseline is None:
1027 y = np.concatenate([y[:1], y, y[-1:]])
1028 elif self._baseline.ndim == 0: # single baseline value
1029 y = np.concatenate([[self._baseline], y, [self._baseline]])
1030 elif self._baseline.ndim == 1: # baseline array
1031 base = np.repeat(self._baseline[idx0:idx1], 2)[::-1]
1032 x = np.concatenate([x, x[::-1]])
1033 y = np.concatenate([base[-1:], y, base[:1],
1034 base[:1], base, base[-1:]])
1035 else: # no baseline
1036 raise ValueError('Invalid `baseline` specified')
1037 if self.orientation == 'vertical':
1038 xy = np.column_stack([x, y])
1039 else:
1040 xy = np.column_stack([y, x])
1041 verts.append(xy)
1042 codes.append([Path.MOVETO] + [Path.LINETO]*(len(xy)-1))
1043 self._path = Path(np.concatenate(verts), np.concatenate(codes))
1044  
1045 def get_data(self):
1046 """Get `.StepPatch` values, edges and baseline as namedtuple."""
1047 StairData = namedtuple('StairData', 'values edges baseline')
1048 return StairData(self._values, self._edges, self._baseline)
1049  
1050 def set_data(self, values=None, edges=None, baseline=None):
1051 """
1052 Set `.StepPatch` values, edges and baseline.
1053  
1054 Parameters
1055 ----------
1056 values : 1D array-like or None
1057 Will not update values, if passing None
1058 edges : 1D array-like, optional
1059 baseline : float, 1D array-like or None
1060 """
1061 if values is None and edges is None and baseline is None:
1062 raise ValueError("Must set *values*, *edges* or *baseline*.")
1063 if values is not None:
1064 self._values = np.asarray(values)
1065 if edges is not None:
1066 self._edges = np.asarray(edges)
1067 if baseline is not None:
1068 self._baseline = np.asarray(baseline)
1069 self._update_path()
1070 self.stale = True
1071  
1072  
1073 class Polygon(Patch):
1074 """A general polygon patch."""
1075  
1076 def __str__(self):
1077 if len(self._path.vertices):
1078 s = "Polygon%d((%g, %g) ...)"
1079 return s % (len(self._path.vertices), *self._path.vertices[0])
1080 else:
1081 return "Polygon0()"
1082  
1083 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1084 def __init__(self, xy, *, closed=True, **kwargs):
1085 """
1086 Parameters
1087 ----------
1088 xy : (N, 2) array
1089  
1090 closed : bool, default: True
1091 Whether the polygon is closed (i.e., has identical start and end
1092 points).
1093  
1094 **kwargs
1095 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1096 """
1097 super().__init__(**kwargs)
1098 self._closed = closed
1099 self.set_xy(xy)
1100  
1101 def get_path(self):
1102 """Get the `.Path` of the polygon."""
1103 return self._path
1104  
1105 def get_closed(self):
1106 """Return whether the polygon is closed."""
1107 return self._closed
1108  
1109 def set_closed(self, closed):
1110 """
1111 Set whether the polygon is closed.
1112  
1113 Parameters
1114 ----------
1115 closed : bool
1116 True if the polygon is closed
1117 """
1118 if self._closed == bool(closed):
1119 return
1120 self._closed = bool(closed)
1121 self.set_xy(self.get_xy())
1122 self.stale = True
1123  
1124 def get_xy(self):
1125 """
1126 Get the vertices of the path.
1127  
1128 Returns
1129 -------
1130 (N, 2) array
1131 The coordinates of the vertices.
1132 """
1133 return self._path.vertices
1134  
1135 def set_xy(self, xy):
1136 """
1137 Set the vertices of the polygon.
1138  
1139 Parameters
1140 ----------
1141 xy : (N, 2) array-like
1142 The coordinates of the vertices.
1143  
1144 Notes
1145 -----
1146 Unlike `.Path`, we do not ignore the last input vertex. If the
1147 polygon is meant to be closed, and the last point of the polygon is not
1148 equal to the first, we assume that the user has not explicitly passed a
1149 ``CLOSEPOLY`` vertex, and add it ourselves.
1150 """
1151 xy = np.asarray(xy)
1152 nverts, _ = xy.shape
1153 if self._closed:
1154 # if the first and last vertex are the "same", then we assume that
1155 # the user explicitly passed the CLOSEPOLY vertex. Otherwise, we
1156 # have to append one since the last vertex will be "ignored" by
1157 # Path
1158 if nverts == 1 or nverts > 1 and (xy[0] != xy[-1]).any():
1159 xy = np.concatenate([xy, [xy[0]]])
1160 else:
1161 # if we aren't closed, and the last vertex matches the first, then
1162 # we assume we have an unnecessary CLOSEPOLY vertex and remove it
1163 if nverts > 2 and (xy[0] == xy[-1]).all():
1164 xy = xy[:-1]
1165 self._path = Path(xy, closed=self._closed)
1166 self.stale = True
1167  
1168 xy = property(get_xy, set_xy,
1169 doc='The vertices of the path as a (N, 2) array.')
1170

1172 class Wedge(Patch):
1173 """Wedge shaped patch."""
1174  
1175 def __str__(self):
1176 pars = (self.center[0], self.center[1], self.r,
1177 self.theta1, self.theta2, self.width)
1178 fmt = "Wedge(center=(%g, %g), r=%g, theta1=%g, theta2=%g, width=%s)"
1179 return fmt % pars
1180  
1181 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1182 def __init__(self, center, r, theta1, theta2, *, width=None, **kwargs):
1183 """
1184 A wedge centered at *x*, *y* center with radius *r* that
1185 sweeps *theta1* to *theta2* (in degrees). If *width* is given,
1186 then a partial wedge is drawn from inner radius *r* - *width*
1187 to outer radius *r*.
1188  
1189 Valid keyword arguments are:
1190  
1191 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1192 """
1193 super().__init__(**kwargs)
1194 self.center = center
1195 self.r, self.width = r, width
1196 self.theta1, self.theta2 = theta1, theta2
1197 self._patch_transform = transforms.IdentityTransform()
1198 self._recompute_path()
1199  
1200 def _recompute_path(self):
1201 # Inner and outer rings are connected unless the annulus is complete
1202 if abs((self.theta2 - self.theta1) - 360) <= 1e-12:
1203 theta1, theta2 = 0, 360
1204 connector = Path.MOVETO
1205 else:
1206 theta1, theta2 = self.theta1, self.theta2
1207 connector = Path.LINETO
1208  
1209 # Form the outer ring
1210 arc = Path.arc(theta1, theta2)
1211  
1212 if self.width is not None:
1213 # Partial annulus needs to draw the outer ring
1214 # followed by a reversed and scaled inner ring
1215 v1 = arc.vertices
1216 v2 = arc.vertices[::-1] * (self.r - self.width) / self.r
1217 v = np.concatenate([v1, v2, [(0, 0)]])
1218 c = [*arc.codes, connector, *arc.codes[1:], Path.CLOSEPOLY]
1219 else:
1220 # Wedge doesn't need an inner ring
1221 v = np.concatenate([arc.vertices, [(0, 0), (0, 0)]])
1222 c = [*arc.codes, connector, Path.CLOSEPOLY]
1223  
1224 # Shift and scale the wedge to the final location.
1225 self._path = Path(v * self.r + self.center, c)
1226  
1227 def set_center(self, center):
1228 self._path = None
1229 self.center = center
1230 self.stale = True
1231  
1232 def set_radius(self, radius):
1233 self._path = None
1234 self.r = radius
1235 self.stale = True
1236  
1237 def set_theta1(self, theta1):
1238 self._path = None
1239 self.theta1 = theta1
1240 self.stale = True
1241  
1242 def set_theta2(self, theta2):
1243 self._path = None
1244 self.theta2 = theta2
1245 self.stale = True
1246  
1247 def set_width(self, width):
1248 self._path = None
1249 self.width = width
1250 self.stale = True
1251  
1252 def get_path(self):
1253 if self._path is None:
1254 self._recompute_path()
1255 return self._path
1256

1269 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1270 def __init__(self, x, y, dx, dy, *, width=1.0, **kwargs):

1273 The width of the arrow is scaled by *width*.
1274

1288 **kwargs

1299 super().__init__(**kwargs)
1300 self._patch_transform = (

1304 .translate(x, y)

1314 class FancyArrow(Polygon):
1315 """
1316 Like Arrow, but lets you set head width and head height independently.
1317 """
1318  
1319 _edge_default = True
1320  
1321 def __str__(self):
1322 return "FancyArrow()"
1323  
1324 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1325 def __init__(self, x, y, dx, dy, *,
1326 width=0.001, length_includes_head=False, head_width=None,
1327 head_length=None, shape='full', overhang=0,
1328 head_starts_at_zero=False, **kwargs):
1329 """
1330 Parameters
1331 ----------
1332 x, y : float
1333 The x and y coordinates of the arrow base.
1334  
1335 dx, dy : float
1336 The length of the arrow along x and y direction.
1337  
1338 width : float, default: 0.001
1339 Width of full arrow tail.
1340  
1341 length_includes_head : bool, default: False
1342 True if head is to be counted in calculating the length.
1343  
1344 head_width : float or None, default: 3*width
1345 Total width of the full arrow head.
1346  
1347 head_length : float or None, default: 1.5*head_width
1348 Length of arrow head.
1349  
1350 shape : {'full', 'left', 'right'}, default: 'full'
1351 Draw the left-half, right-half, or full arrow.
1352  
1353 overhang : float, default: 0
1354 Fraction that the arrow is swept back (0 overhang means
1355 triangular shape). Can be negative or greater than one.
1356  
1357 head_starts_at_zero : bool, default: False
1358 If True, the head starts being drawn at coordinate 0
1359 instead of ending at coordinate 0.
1360  
1361 **kwargs
1362 `.Patch` properties:
1363  
1364 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1365 """
1366 self._x = x
1367 self._y = y
1368 self._dx = dx
1369 self._dy = dy
1370 self._width = width
1371 self._length_includes_head = length_includes_head
1372 self._head_width = head_width
1373 self._head_length = head_length
1374 self._shape = shape
1375 self._overhang = overhang
1376 self._head_starts_at_zero = head_starts_at_zero
1377 self._make_verts()
1378 super().__init__(self.verts, closed=True, **kwargs)
1379  
1380 def set_data(self, *, x=None, y=None, dx=None, dy=None, width=None,
1381 head_width=None, head_length=None):
1382 """
1383 Set `.FancyArrow` x, y, dx, dy, width, head_with, and head_length.
1384 Values left as None will not be updated.
1385  
1386 Parameters
1387 ----------
1388 x, y : float or None, default: None
1389 The x and y coordinates of the arrow base.
1390  
1391 dx, dy : float or None, default: None
1392 The length of the arrow along x and y direction.
1393  
1394 width : float or None, default: None
1395 Width of full arrow tail.
1396  
1397 head_width : float or None, default: None
1398 Total width of the full arrow head.
1399  
1400 head_length : float or None, default: None
1401 Length of arrow head.
1402 """
1403 if x is not None:
1404 self._x = x
1405 if y is not None:
1406 self._y = y
1407 if dx is not None:
1408 self._dx = dx
1409 if dy is not None:
1410 self._dy = dy
1411 if width is not None:
1412 self._width = width
1413 if head_width is not None:
1414 self._head_width = head_width
1415 if head_length is not None:
1416 self._head_length = head_length
1417 self._make_verts()
1418 self.set_xy(self.verts)
1419  
1420 def _make_verts(self):
1421 if self._head_width is None:
1422 head_width = 3 * self._width
1423 else:
1424 head_width = self._head_width
1425 if self._head_length is None:
1426 head_length = 1.5 * head_width
1427 else:
1428 head_length = self._head_length
1429  
1430 distance = np.hypot(self._dx, self._dy)
1431  
1432 if self._length_includes_head:
1433 length = distance
1434 else:
1435 length = distance + head_length
1436 if not length:
1437 self.verts = np.empty([0, 2]) # display nothing if empty
1438 else:
1439 # start by drawing horizontal arrow, point at (0, 0)
1440 hw, hl = head_width, head_length
1441 hs, lw = self._overhang, self._width
1442 left_half_arrow = np.array([
1443 [0.0, 0.0], # tip
1444 [-hl, -hw / 2], # leftmost
1445 [-hl * (1 - hs), -lw / 2], # meets stem
1446 [-length, -lw / 2], # bottom left
1447 [-length, 0],
1448 ])
1449 # if we're not including the head, shift up by head length
1450 if not self._length_includes_head:
1451 left_half_arrow += [head_length, 0]
1452 # if the head starts at 0, shift up by another head length
1453 if self._head_starts_at_zero:
1454 left_half_arrow += [head_length / 2, 0]
1455 # figure out the shape, and complete accordingly
1456 if self._shape == 'left':
1457 coords = left_half_arrow
1458 else:
1459 right_half_arrow = left_half_arrow * [1, -1]
1460 if self._shape == 'right':
1461 coords = right_half_arrow
1462 elif self._shape == 'full':
1463 # The half-arrows contain the midpoint of the stem,
1464 # which we can omit from the full arrow. Including it
1465 # twice caused a problem with xpdf.
1466 coords = np.concatenate([left_half_arrow[:-1],
1467 right_half_arrow[-2::-1]])
1468 else:
1469 raise ValueError(f"Got unknown shape: {self._shape!r}")
1470 if distance != 0:
1471 cx = self._dx / distance
1472 sx = self._dy / distance
1473 else:
1474 # Account for division by zero
1475 cx, sx = 0, 1
1476 M = [[cx, sx], [-sx, cx]]
1477 self.verts = np.dot(coords, M) + [
1478 self._x + self._dx,
1479 self._y + self._dy,
1480 ]
1481  
1482  
1483 _docstring.interpd.update(
1484 FancyArrow="\n".join(
1485 (inspect.getdoc(FancyArrow.__init__) or "").splitlines()[2:]))
1486

1488 class CirclePolygon(RegularPolygon):

1852 def _transform_verts(self, verts, a, b):
1853 return transforms.Affine2D() \
1854 .scale(*self._convert_xy_units((a, b))) \
1855 .rotate_deg(self.angle) \
1856 .translate(*self._convert_xy_units(self.center)) \
1857 .transform(verts)
1858  
1859 def _recompute_path(self):
1860 # circular arc
1861 arc = Path.arc(0, 360)
1862  
1863 # annulus needs to draw an outer ring
1864 # followed by a reversed and scaled inner ring
1865 a, b, w = self.a, self.b, self.width
1866 v1 = self._transform_verts(arc.vertices, a, b)
1867 v2 = self._transform_verts(arc.vertices[::-1], a - w, b - w)
1868 v = np.vstack([v1, v2, v1[0, :], (0, 0)])
1869 c = np.hstack([arc.codes, Path.MOVETO,
1870 arc.codes[1:], Path.MOVETO,
1871 Path.CLOSEPOLY])
1872 self._path = Path(v, c)
1873  
1874 def get_path(self):
1875 if self._path is None:
1876 self._recompute_path()
1877 return self._path

1922 class Arc(Ellipse):
1923 """
1924 An elliptical arc, i.e. a segment of an ellipse.
1925  
1926 Due to internal optimizations, the arc cannot be filled.
1927 """
1928  
1929 def __str__(self):
1930 pars = (self.center[0], self.center[1], self.width,
1931 self.height, self.angle, self.theta1, self.theta2)
1932 fmt = ("Arc(xy=(%g, %g), width=%g, "
1933 "height=%g, angle=%g, theta1=%g, theta2=%g)")
1934 return fmt % pars
1935  
1936 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
1937 def __init__(self, xy, width, height, *,
1938 angle=0.0, theta1=0.0, theta2=360.0, **kwargs):
1939 """
1940 Parameters
1941 ----------
1942 xy : (float, float)
1943 The center of the ellipse.
1944  
1945 width : float
1946 The length of the horizontal axis.
1947  
1948 height : float
1949 The length of the vertical axis.
1950  
1951 angle : float
1952 Rotation of the ellipse in degrees (counterclockwise).
1953  
1954 theta1, theta2 : float, default: 0, 360
1955 Starting and ending angles of the arc in degrees. These values
1956 are relative to *angle*, e.g. if *angle* = 45 and *theta1* = 90
1957 the absolute starting angle is 135.
1958 Default *theta1* = 0, *theta2* = 360, i.e. a complete ellipse.
1959 The arc is drawn in the counterclockwise direction.
1960 Angles greater than or equal to 360, or smaller than 0, are
1961 represented by an equivalent angle in the range [0, 360), by
1962 taking the input value mod 360.
1963  
1964 Other Parameters
1965 ----------------
1966 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties
1967 Most `.Patch` properties are supported as keyword arguments,
1968 except *fill* and *facecolor* because filling is not supported.
1969  
1970 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
1971 """
1972 fill = kwargs.setdefault('fill', False)
1973 if fill:
1974 raise ValueError("Arc objects cannot be filled")
1975  
1976 super().__init__(xy, width, height, angle=angle, **kwargs)
1977  
1978 self.theta1 = theta1
1979 self.theta2 = theta2
1980 (self._theta1, self._theta2, self._stretched_width,
1981 self._stretched_height) = self._theta_stretch()
1982 self._path = Path.arc(self._theta1, self._theta2)
1983  
1984 @artist.allow_rasterization
1985 def draw(self, renderer):
1986 """
1987 Draw the arc to the given *renderer*.
1988  
1989 Notes
1990 -----
1991 Ellipses are normally drawn using an approximation that uses
1992 eight cubic Bezier splines. The error of this approximation
1993 is 1.89818e-6, according to this unverified source:
1994  
1995 Lancaster, Don. *Approximating a Circle or an Ellipse Using
1996 Four Bezier Cubic Splines.*
1997  
1998 https://www.tinaja.com/glib/ellipse4.pdf
1999  
2000 There is a use case where very large ellipses must be drawn
2001 with very high accuracy, and it is too expensive to render the
2002 entire ellipse with enough segments (either splines or line
2003 segments). Therefore, in the case where either radius of the
2004 ellipse is large enough that the error of the spline
2005 approximation will be visible (greater than one pixel offset
2006 from the ideal), a different technique is used.
2007  
2008 In that case, only the visible parts of the ellipse are drawn,
2009 with each visible arc using a fixed number of spline segments
2010 (8). The algorithm proceeds as follows:
2011  
2012 1. The points where the ellipse intersects the axes (or figure)
2013 bounding box are located. (This is done by performing an inverse
2014 transformation on the bbox such that it is relative to the unit
2015 circle -- this makes the intersection calculation much easier than
2016 doing rotated ellipse intersection directly.)
2017  
2018 This uses the "line intersecting a circle" algorithm from:
2019  
2020 Vince, John. *Geometry for Computer Graphics: Formulae,
2021 Examples & Proofs.* London: Springer-Verlag, 2005.
2022  
2023 2. The angles of each of the intersection points are calculated.
2024  
2025 3. Proceeding counterclockwise starting in the positive
2026 x-direction, each of the visible arc-segments between the
2027 pairs of vertices are drawn using the Bezier arc
2028 approximation technique implemented in `.Path.arc`.
2029 """
2030 if not self.get_visible():
2031 return
2032  
2033 self._recompute_transform()
2034  
2035 self._update_path()
2036 # Get width and height in pixels we need to use
2037 # `self.get_data_transform` rather than `self.get_transform`
2038 # because we want the transform from dataspace to the
2039 # screen space to estimate how big the arc will be in physical
2040 # units when rendered (the transform that we get via
2041 # `self.get_transform()` goes from an idealized unit-radius
2042 # space to screen space).
2043 data_to_screen_trans = self.get_data_transform()
2044 pwidth, pheight = (
2045 data_to_screen_trans.transform((self._stretched_width,
2046 self._stretched_height)) -
2047 data_to_screen_trans.transform((0, 0)))
2048 inv_error = (1.0 / 1.89818e-6) * 0.5
2049  
2050 if pwidth < inv_error and pheight < inv_error:
2051 return Patch.draw(self, renderer)
2052  
2053 def line_circle_intersect(x0, y0, x1, y1):
2054 dx = x1 - x0
2055 dy = y1 - y0
2056 dr2 = dx * dx + dy * dy
2057 D = x0 * y1 - x1 * y0
2058 D2 = D * D
2059 discrim = dr2 - D2
2060 if discrim >= 0.0:
2061 sign_dy = np.copysign(1, dy) # +/-1, never 0.
2062 sqrt_discrim = np.sqrt(discrim)
2063 return np.array(
2064 [[(D * dy + sign_dy * dx * sqrt_discrim) / dr2,
2065 (-D * dx + abs(dy) * sqrt_discrim) / dr2],
2066 [(D * dy - sign_dy * dx * sqrt_discrim) / dr2,
2067 (-D * dx - abs(dy) * sqrt_discrim) / dr2]])
2068 else:
2069 return np.empty((0, 2))
2070  
2071 def segment_circle_intersect(x0, y0, x1, y1):
2072 epsilon = 1e-9
2073 if x1 < x0:
2074 x0e, x1e = x1, x0
2075 else:
2076 x0e, x1e = x0, x1
2077 if y1 < y0:
2078 y0e, y1e = y1, y0
2079 else:
2080 y0e, y1e = y0, y1
2081 xys = line_circle_intersect(x0, y0, x1, y1)
2082 xs, ys = xys.T
2083 return xys[
2084 (x0e - epsilon < xs) & (xs < x1e + epsilon)
2085 & (y0e - epsilon < ys) & (ys < y1e + epsilon)
2086 ]
2087  
2088 # Transform the axes (or figure) box_path so that it is relative to
2089 # the unit circle in the same way that it is relative to the desired
2090 # ellipse.
2091 box_path_transform = (
2092 transforms.BboxTransformTo((self.axes or self.figure).bbox)
2093 - self.get_transform())
2094 box_path = Path.unit_rectangle().transformed(box_path_transform)
2095  
2096 thetas = set()
2097 # For each of the point pairs, there is a line segment
2098 for p0, p1 in zip(box_path.vertices[:-1], box_path.vertices[1:]):
2099 xy = segment_circle_intersect(*p0, *p1)
2100 x, y = xy.T
2101 # arctan2 return [-pi, pi), the rest of our angles are in
2102 # [0, 360], adjust as needed.
2103 theta = (np.rad2deg(np.arctan2(y, x)) + 360) % 360
2104 thetas.update(
2105 theta[(self._theta1 < theta) & (theta < self._theta2)])
2106 thetas = sorted(thetas) + [self._theta2]
2107 last_theta = self._theta1
2108 theta1_rad = np.deg2rad(self._theta1)
2109 inside = box_path.contains_point(
2110 (np.cos(theta1_rad), np.sin(theta1_rad))
2111 )
2112  
2113 # save original path
2114 path_original = self._path
2115 for theta in thetas:
2116 if inside:
2117 self._path = Path.arc(last_theta, theta, 8)
2118 Patch.draw(self, renderer)
2119 inside = False
2120 else:
2121 inside = True
2122 last_theta = theta
2123  
2124 # restore original path
2125 self._path = path_original
2126  
2127 def _update_path(self):
2128 # Compute new values and update and set new _path if any value changed
2129 stretched = self._theta_stretch()
2130 if any(a != b for a, b in zip(
2131 stretched, (self._theta1, self._theta2, self._stretched_width,
2132 self._stretched_height))):
2133 (self._theta1, self._theta2, self._stretched_width,
2134 self._stretched_height) = stretched
2135 self._path = Path.arc(self._theta1, self._theta2)
2136  
2137 def _theta_stretch(self):
2138 # If the width and height of ellipse are not equal, take into account
2139 # stretching when calculating angles to draw between
2140 def theta_stretch(theta, scale):
2141 theta = np.deg2rad(theta)
2142 x = np.cos(theta)
2143 y = np.sin(theta)
2144 stheta = np.rad2deg(np.arctan2(scale * y, x))
2145 # arctan2 has the range [-pi, pi], we expect [0, 2*pi]
2146 return (stheta + 360) % 360
2147  
2148 width = self.convert_xunits(self.width)
2149 height = self.convert_yunits(self.height)
2150 if (
2151 # if we need to stretch the angles because we are distorted
2152 width != height
2153 # and we are not doing a full circle.
2154 #
2155 # 0 and 360 do not exactly round-trip through the angle
2156 # stretching (due to both float precision limitations and
2157 # the difference between the range of arctan2 [-pi, pi] and
2158 # this method [0, 360]) so avoid doing it if we don't have to.
2159 and not (self.theta1 != self.theta2 and
2160 self.theta1 % 360 == self.theta2 % 360)
2161 ):
2162 theta1 = theta_stretch(self.theta1, width / height)
2163 theta2 = theta_stretch(self.theta2, width / height)
2164 return theta1, theta2, width, height
2165 return self.theta1, self.theta2, width, height
2166

2168 def bbox_artist(artist, renderer, props=None, fill=True):
2169 """
2170 A debug function to draw a rectangle around the bounding
2171 box returned by an artist's `.Artist.get_window_extent`
2172 to test whether the artist is returning the correct bbox.
2173  
2174 *props* is a dict of rectangle props with the additional property
2175 'pad' that sets the padding around the bbox in points.
2176 """
2177 if props is None:
2178 props = {}
2179 props = props.copy() # don't want to alter the pad externally
2180 pad = props.pop('pad', 4)
2181 pad = renderer.points_to_pixels(pad)
2182 bbox = artist.get_window_extent(renderer)
2183 r = Rectangle(
2184 xy=(bbox.x0 - pad / 2, bbox.y0 - pad / 2),
2185 width=bbox.width + pad, height=bbox.height + pad,
2186 fill=fill, transform=transforms.IdentityTransform(), clip_on=False)
2187 r.update(props)
2188 r.draw(renderer)

2204 class _Style:
2205 """
2206 A base class for the Styles. It is meant to be a container class,
2207 where actual styles are declared as subclass of it, and it
2208 provides some helper functions.
2209 """
2210  
2211 def __init_subclass__(cls):
2212 # Automatically perform docstring interpolation on the subclasses:
2213 # This allows listing the supported styles via
2214 # - %(BoxStyle:table)s
2215 # - %(ConnectionStyle:table)s
2216 # - %(ArrowStyle:table)s
2217 # and additionally adding .. ACCEPTS: blocks via
2218 # - %(BoxStyle:table_and_accepts)s
2219 # - %(ConnectionStyle:table_and_accepts)s
2220 # - %(ArrowStyle:table_and_accepts)s
2221 _docstring.interpd.update({
2222 f"{cls.__name__}:table": cls.pprint_styles(),
2223 f"{cls.__name__}:table_and_accepts": (
2224 cls.pprint_styles()
2225 + "\n\n .. ACCEPTS: ["
2226 + "|".join(map(" '{}' ".format, cls._style_list))
2227 + "]")
2228 })
2229  
2230 def __new__(cls, stylename, **kwargs):
2231 """Return the instance of the subclass with the given style name."""
2232 # The "class" should have the _style_list attribute, which is a mapping
2233 # of style names to style classes.
2234 _list = stylename.replace(" ", "").split(",")
2235 _name = _list[0].lower()
2236 try:
2237 _cls = cls._style_list[_name]
2238 except KeyError as err:
2239 raise ValueError(f"Unknown style: {stylename!r}") from err
2240 try:
2241 _args_pair = [cs.split("=") for cs in _list[1:]]
2242 _args = {k: float(v) for k, v in _args_pair}
2243 except ValueError as err:
2244 raise ValueError(
2245 f"Incorrect style argument: {stylename!r}") from err
2246 return _cls(**{**_args, **kwargs})

2248 @classmethod
2249 def get_styles(cls):
2250 """Return a dictionary of available styles."""
2251 return cls._style_list
2252  
2253 @classmethod
2254 def pprint_styles(cls):
2255 """Return the available styles as pretty-printed string."""
2256 table = [('Class', 'Name', 'Attrs'),
2257 *[(cls.__name__,
2258 # Add backquotes, as - and | have special meaning in reST.
2259 f'``{name}``',
2260 # [1:-1] drops the surrounding parentheses.
2261 str(inspect.signature(cls))[1:-1] or 'None')
2262 for name, cls in cls._style_list.items()]]
2263 # Convert to rst table.
2264 col_len = [max(len(cell) for cell in column) for column in zip(*table)]
2265 table_formatstr = ' '.join('=' * cl for cl in col_len)
2266 rst_table = '\n'.join([
2267 '',
2268 table_formatstr,
2269 ' '.join(cell.ljust(cl) for cell, cl in zip(table[0], col_len)),
2270 table_formatstr,
2271 *[' '.join(cell.ljust(cl) for cell, cl in zip(row, col_len))
2272 for row in table[1:]],
2273 table_formatstr,
2274 ])
2275 return textwrap.indent(rst_table, prefix=' ' * 4)

2277 @classmethod
2278 def register(cls, name, style):
2279 """Register a new style."""
2280 if not issubclass(style, cls._Base):
2281 raise ValueError(f"{style} must be a subclass of {cls._Base}")
2282 cls._style_list[name] = style
2283  
2284  
2285 def _register_style(style_list, cls=None, *, name=None):
2286 """Class decorator that stashes a class in a (style) dictionary."""
2287 if cls is None:
2288 return functools.partial(_register_style, style_list, name=name)
2289 style_list[name or cls.__name__.lower()] = cls
2290 return cls

2398 class LArrow:

2403 Parameters
2404 ----------
2405 pad : float, default: 0.3
2406 The amount of padding around the original box.

2477 class Round:
2478 """A box with round corners."""
2479  
2480 def __init__(self, pad=0.3, rounding_size=None):
2481 """
2482 Parameters
2483 ----------
2484 pad : float, default: 0.3
2485 The amount of padding around the original box.
2486 rounding_size : float, default: *pad*
2487 Radius of the corners.
2488 """
2489 self.pad = pad
2490 self.rounding_size = rounding_size
2491  
2492 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2493  
2494 # padding
2495 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2496  
2497 # size of the rounding corner
2498 if self.rounding_size:
2499 dr = mutation_size * self.rounding_size
2500 else:
2501 dr = pad
2502  
2503 width, height = width + 2 * pad, height + 2 * pad
2504  
2505 x0, y0 = x0 - pad, y0 - pad,
2506 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2507  
2508 # Round corners are implemented as quadratic Bezier, e.g.,
2509 # [(x0, y0-dr), (x0, y0), (x0+dr, y0)] for lower left corner.
2510 cp = [(x0 + dr, y0),
2511 (x1 - dr, y0),
2512 (x1, y0), (x1, y0 + dr),
2513 (x1, y1 - dr),
2514 (x1, y1), (x1 - dr, y1),
2515 (x0 + dr, y1),
2516 (x0, y1), (x0, y1 - dr),
2517 (x0, y0 + dr),
2518 (x0, y0), (x0 + dr, y0),
2519 (x0 + dr, y0)]
2520  
2521 com = [Path.MOVETO,
2522 Path.LINETO,
2523 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2524 Path.LINETO,
2525 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2526 Path.LINETO,
2527 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2528 Path.LINETO,
2529 Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3,
2530 Path.CLOSEPOLY]
2531  
2532 return Path(cp, com)

2583 @_register_style(_style_list)
2584 class Sawtooth:
2585 """A box with a sawtooth outline."""
2586  
2587 def __init__(self, pad=0.3, tooth_size=None):
2588 """
2589 Parameters
2590 ----------
2591 pad : float, default: 0.3
2592 The amount of padding around the original box.
2593 tooth_size : float, default: *pad*/2
2594 Size of the sawtooth.
2595 """
2596 self.pad = pad
2597 self.tooth_size = tooth_size
2598  
2599 def _get_sawtooth_vertices(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2600  
2601 # padding
2602 pad = mutation_size * self.pad
2603  
2604 # size of sawtooth
2605 if self.tooth_size is None:
2606 tooth_size = self.pad * .5 * mutation_size
2607 else:
2608 tooth_size = self.tooth_size * mutation_size
2609  
2610 hsz = tooth_size / 2
2611 width = width + 2 * pad - tooth_size
2612 height = height + 2 * pad - tooth_size
2613  
2614 # the sizes of the vertical and horizontal sawtooth are
2615 # separately adjusted to fit the given box size.
2616 dsx_n = round((width - tooth_size) / (tooth_size * 2)) * 2
2617 dsy_n = round((height - tooth_size) / (tooth_size * 2)) * 2
2618  
2619 x0, y0 = x0 - pad + hsz, y0 - pad + hsz
2620 x1, y1 = x0 + width, y0 + height
2621  
2622 xs = [
2623 x0, *np.linspace(x0 + hsz, x1 - hsz, 2 * dsx_n + 1), # bottom
2624 *([x1, x1 + hsz, x1, x1 - hsz] * dsy_n)[:2*dsy_n+2], # right
2625 x1, *np.linspace(x1 - hsz, x0 + hsz, 2 * dsx_n + 1), # top
2626 *([x0, x0 - hsz, x0, x0 + hsz] * dsy_n)[:2*dsy_n+2], # left
2627 ]
2628 ys = [
2629 *([y0, y0 - hsz, y0, y0 + hsz] * dsx_n)[:2*dsx_n+2], # bottom
2630 y0, *np.linspace(y0 + hsz, y1 - hsz, 2 * dsy_n + 1), # right
2631 *([y1, y1 + hsz, y1, y1 - hsz] * dsx_n)[:2*dsx_n+2], # top
2632 y1, *np.linspace(y1 - hsz, y0 + hsz, 2 * dsy_n + 1), # left
2633 ]
2634  
2635 return [*zip(xs, ys), (xs[0], ys[0])]
2636  
2637 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2638 saw_vertices = self._get_sawtooth_vertices(x0, y0, width,
2639 height, mutation_size)
2640 return Path(saw_vertices, closed=True)
2641  
2642 @_register_style(_style_list)
2643 class Roundtooth(Sawtooth):
2644 """A box with a rounded sawtooth outline."""
2645  
2646 def __call__(self, x0, y0, width, height, mutation_size):
2647 saw_vertices = self._get_sawtooth_vertices(x0, y0,
2648 width, height,
2649 mutation_size)
2650 # Add a trailing vertex to allow us to close the polygon correctly
2651 saw_vertices = np.concatenate([saw_vertices, [saw_vertices[0]]])
2652 codes = ([Path.MOVETO] +
2653 [Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3] * ((len(saw_vertices)-1)//2) +
2654 [Path.CLOSEPOLY])
2655 return Path(saw_vertices, codes)

2658 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
2659 class ConnectionStyle(_Style):
2660 """
2661 `ConnectionStyle` is a container class which defines
2662 several connectionstyle classes, which is used to create a path
2663 between two points. These are mainly used with `FancyArrowPatch`.
2664  
2665 A connectionstyle object can be either created as::
2666  
2667 ConnectionStyle.Arc3(rad=0.2)
2668  
2669 or::
2670  
2671 ConnectionStyle("Arc3", rad=0.2)
2672  
2673 or::
2674  
2675 ConnectionStyle("Arc3, rad=0.2")
2676  
2677 The following classes are defined
2678  
2679 %(ConnectionStyle:table)s
2680  
2681 An instance of any connection style class is a callable object,
2682 whose call signature is::
2683  
2684 __call__(self, posA, posB,
2685 patchA=None, patchB=None,
2686 shrinkA=2., shrinkB=2.)
2687  
2688 and it returns a `.Path` instance. *posA* and *posB* are
2689 tuples of (x, y) coordinates of the two points to be
2690 connected. *patchA* (or *patchB*) is given, the returned path is
2691 clipped so that it start (or end) from the boundary of the
2692 patch. The path is further shrunk by *shrinkA* (or *shrinkB*)
2693 which is given in points.
2694 """
2695  
2696 _style_list = {}
2697  
2698 class _Base:
2699 """
2700 A base class for connectionstyle classes. The subclass needs
2701 to implement a *connect* method whose call signature is::
2702  
2703 connect(posA, posB)
2704  
2705 where posA and posB are tuples of x, y coordinates to be
2706 connected. The method needs to return a path connecting two
2707 points. This base class defines a __call__ method, and a few
2708 helper methods.
2709 """
2710  
2711 @_api.deprecated("3.7")
2712 class SimpleEvent:
2713 def __init__(self, xy):
2714 self.x, self.y = xy
2715  
2716 def _in_patch(self, patch):
2717 """
2718 Return a predicate function testing whether a point *xy* is
2719 contained in *patch*.
2720 """
2721 return lambda xy: patch.contains(
2722 SimpleNamespace(x=xy[0], y=xy[1]))[0]
2723  
2724 def _clip(self, path, in_start, in_stop):
2725 """
2726 Clip *path* at its start by the region where *in_start* returns
2727 True, and at its stop by the region where *in_stop* returns True.
2728  
2729 The original path is assumed to start in the *in_start* region and
2730 to stop in the *in_stop* region.
2731 """
2732 if in_start:
2733 try:
2734 _, path = split_path_inout(path, in_start)
2735 except ValueError:
2736 pass
2737 if in_stop:
2738 try:
2739 path, _ = split_path_inout(path, in_stop)
2740 except ValueError:
2741 pass
2742 return path
2743  
2744 def __call__(self, posA, posB,
2745 shrinkA=2., shrinkB=2., patchA=None, patchB=None):
2746 """
2747 Call the *connect* method to create a path between *posA* and
2748 *posB*; then clip and shrink the path.
2749 """
2750 path = self.connect(posA, posB)
2751 path = self._clip(
2752 path,
2753 self._in_patch(patchA) if patchA else None,
2754 self._in_patch(patchB) if patchB else None,
2755 )
2756 path = self._clip(
2757 path,
2758 inside_circle(*path.vertices[0], shrinkA) if shrinkA else None,
2759 inside_circle(*path.vertices[-1], shrinkB) if shrinkB else None
2760 )
2761 return path
2762  
2763 @_register_style(_style_list)
2764 class Arc3(_Base):
2765 """
2766 Creates a simple quadratic Bézier curve between two
2767 points. The curve is created so that the middle control point
2768 (C1) is located at the same distance from the start (C0) and
2769 end points(C2) and the distance of the C1 to the line
2770 connecting C0-C2 is *rad* times the distance of C0-C2.
2771 """
2772  
2773 def __init__(self, rad=0.):
2774 """
2775 Parameters
2776 ----------
2777 rad : float
2778 Curvature of the curve.
2779 """
2780 self.rad = rad
2781  
2782 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2783 x1, y1 = posA
2784 x2, y2 = posB
2785 x12, y12 = (x1 + x2) / 2., (y1 + y2) / 2.
2786 dx, dy = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
2787  
2788 f = self.rad
2789  
2790 cx, cy = x12 + f * dy, y12 - f * dx
2791  
2792 vertices = [(x1, y1),
2793 (cx, cy),
2794 (x2, y2)]
2795 codes = [Path.MOVETO,
2796 Path.CURVE3,
2797 Path.CURVE3]
2798  
2799 return Path(vertices, codes)
2800  
2801 @_register_style(_style_list)
2802 class Angle3(_Base):
2803 """
2804 Creates a simple quadratic Bézier curve between two points. The middle
2805 control point is placed at the intersecting point of two lines which
2806 cross the start and end point, and have a slope of *angleA* and
2807 *angleB*, respectively.
2808 """
2809  
2810 def __init__(self, angleA=90, angleB=0):
2811 """
2812 Parameters
2813 ----------
2814 angleA : float
2815 Starting angle of the path.
2816  
2817 angleB : float
2818 Ending angle of the path.
2819 """
2820  
2821 self.angleA = angleA
2822 self.angleB = angleB
2823  
2824 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2825 x1, y1 = posA
2826 x2, y2 = posB
2827  
2828 cosA = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleA))
2829 sinA = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleA))
2830 cosB = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleB))
2831 sinB = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleB))
2832  
2833 cx, cy = get_intersection(x1, y1, cosA, sinA,
2834 x2, y2, cosB, sinB)
2835  
2836 vertices = [(x1, y1), (cx, cy), (x2, y2)]
2837 codes = [Path.MOVETO, Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3]
2838  
2839 return Path(vertices, codes)
2840  
2841 @_register_style(_style_list)
2842 class Angle(_Base):
2843 """
2844 Creates a piecewise continuous quadratic Bézier path between two
2845 points. The path has a one passing-through point placed at the
2846 intersecting point of two lines which cross the start and end point,
2847 and have a slope of *angleA* and *angleB*, respectively.
2848 The connecting edges are rounded with *rad*.
2849 """
2850  
2851 def __init__(self, angleA=90, angleB=0, rad=0.):
2852 """
2853 Parameters
2854 ----------
2855 angleA : float
2856 Starting angle of the path.
2857  
2858 angleB : float
2859 Ending angle of the path.
2860  
2861 rad : float
2862 Rounding radius of the edge.
2863 """
2864  
2865 self.angleA = angleA
2866 self.angleB = angleB
2867  
2868 self.rad = rad
2869  
2870 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2871 x1, y1 = posA
2872 x2, y2 = posB
2873  
2874 cosA = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleA))
2875 sinA = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleA))
2876 cosB = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleB))
2877 sinB = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleB))
2878  
2879 cx, cy = get_intersection(x1, y1, cosA, sinA,
2880 x2, y2, cosB, sinB)
2881  
2882 vertices = [(x1, y1)]
2883 codes = [Path.MOVETO]
2884  
2885 if self.rad == 0.:
2886 vertices.append((cx, cy))
2887 codes.append(Path.LINETO)
2888 else:
2889 dx1, dy1 = x1 - cx, y1 - cy
2890 d1 = np.hypot(dx1, dy1)
2891 f1 = self.rad / d1
2892 dx2, dy2 = x2 - cx, y2 - cy
2893 d2 = np.hypot(dx2, dy2)
2894 f2 = self.rad / d2
2895 vertices.extend([(cx + dx1 * f1, cy + dy1 * f1),
2896 (cx, cy),
2897 (cx + dx2 * f2, cy + dy2 * f2)])
2898 codes.extend([Path.LINETO, Path.CURVE3, Path.CURVE3])
2899  
2900 vertices.append((x2, y2))
2901 codes.append(Path.LINETO)
2902  
2903 return Path(vertices, codes)
2904  
2905 @_register_style(_style_list)
2906 class Arc(_Base):
2907 """
2908 Creates a piecewise continuous quadratic Bézier path between two
2909 points. The path can have two passing-through points, a
2910 point placed at the distance of *armA* and angle of *angleA* from
2911 point A, another point with respect to point B. The edges are
2912 rounded with *rad*.
2913 """
2914  
2915 def __init__(self, angleA=0, angleB=0, armA=None, armB=None, rad=0.):
2916 """
2917 Parameters
2918 ----------
2919 angleA : float
2920 Starting angle of the path.
2921  
2922 angleB : float
2923 Ending angle of the path.
2924  
2925 armA : float or None
2926 Length of the starting arm.
2927  
2928 armB : float or None
2929 Length of the ending arm.
2930  
2931 rad : float
2932 Rounding radius of the edges.
2933 """
2934  
2935 self.angleA = angleA
2936 self.angleB = angleB
2937 self.armA = armA
2938 self.armB = armB
2939  
2940 self.rad = rad
2941  
2942 def connect(self, posA, posB):
2943 x1, y1 = posA
2944 x2, y2 = posB
2945  
2946 vertices = [(x1, y1)]
2947 rounded = []
2948 codes = [Path.MOVETO]
2949  
2950 if self.armA:
2951 cosA = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleA))
2952 sinA = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleA))
2953 # x_armA, y_armB
2954 d = self.armA - self.rad
2955 rounded.append((x1 + d * cosA, y1 + d * sinA))
2956 d = self.armA
2957 rounded.append((x1 + d * cosA, y1 + d * sinA))
2958  
2959 if self.armB:
2960 cosB = math.cos(math.radians(self.angleB))
2961 sinB = math.sin(math.radians(self.angleB))
2962 x_armB, y_armB = x2 + self.armB * cosB, y2 + self.armB * sinB
2963  
2964 if rounded:
2965 xp, yp = rounded[-1]
2966 dx, dy = x_armB - xp, y_armB - yp
2967 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
2968  
2969 rounded.append((xp + self.rad * dx / dd,
2970 yp + self.rad * dy / dd))
2971 vertices.extend(rounded)
2972 codes.extend([Path.LINETO,
2973 Path.CURVE3,
2974 Path.CURVE3])
2975 else:
2976 xp, yp = vertices[-1]
2977 dx, dy = x_armB - xp, y_armB - yp
2978 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
2979  
2980 d = dd - self.rad
2981 rounded = [(xp + d * dx / dd, yp + d * dy / dd),
2982 (x_armB, y_armB)]
2983  
2984 if rounded:
2985 xp, yp = rounded[-1]
2986 dx, dy = x2 - xp, y2 - yp
2987 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
2988  
2989 rounded.append((xp + self.rad * dx / dd,
2990 yp + self.rad * dy / dd))
2991 vertices.extend(rounded)
2992 codes.extend([Path.LINETO,
2993 Path.CURVE3,
2994 Path.CURVE3])
2995  
2996 vertices.append((x2, y2))
2997 codes.append(Path.LINETO)
2998  
2999 return Path(vertices, codes)
3000  
3001 @_register_style(_style_list)
3002 class Bar(_Base):
3003 """
3004 A line with *angle* between A and B with *armA* and *armB*. One of the
3005 arms is extended so that they are connected in a right angle. The
3006 length of *armA* is determined by (*armA* + *fraction* x AB distance).
3007 Same for *armB*.
3008 """
3009  
3010 def __init__(self, armA=0., armB=0., fraction=0.3, angle=None):
3011 """
3012 Parameters
3013 ----------
3014 armA : float
3015 Minimum length of armA.
3016  
3017 armB : float
3018 Minimum length of armB.
3019  
3020 fraction : float
3021 A fraction of the distance between two points that will be
3022 added to armA and armB.
3023  
3024 angle : float or None
3025 Angle of the connecting line (if None, parallel to A and B).
3026 """
3027 self.armA = armA
3028 self.armB = armB
3029 self.fraction = fraction
3030 self.angle = angle
3031  
3032 def connect(self, posA, posB):
3033 x1, y1 = posA
3034 x20, y20 = x2, y2 = posB
3035  
3036 theta1 = math.atan2(y2 - y1, x2 - x1)
3037 dx, dy = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
3038 dd = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3039 ddx, ddy = dx / dd, dy / dd
3040  
3041 armA, armB = self.armA, self.armB
3042  
3043 if self.angle is not None:
3044 theta0 = np.deg2rad(self.angle)
3045 dtheta = theta1 - theta0
3046 dl = dd * math.sin(dtheta)
3047 dL = dd * math.cos(dtheta)
3048 x2, y2 = x1 + dL * math.cos(theta0), y1 + dL * math.sin(theta0)
3049 armB = armB - dl
3050  
3051 # update
3052 dx, dy = x2 - x1, y2 - y1
3053 dd2 = (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3054 ddx, ddy = dx / dd2, dy / dd2
3055  
3056 arm = max(armA, armB)
3057 f = self.fraction * dd + arm
3058  
3059 cx1, cy1 = x1 + f * ddy, y1 - f * ddx
3060 cx2, cy2 = x2 + f * ddy, y2 - f * ddx
3061  
3062 vertices = [(x1, y1),
3063 (cx1, cy1),
3064 (cx2, cy2),
3065 (x20, y20)]
3066 codes = [Path.MOVETO,
3067 Path.LINETO,
3068 Path.LINETO,
3069 Path.LINETO]
3070  
3071 return Path(vertices, codes)
3072  
3073  
3074 def _point_along_a_line(x0, y0, x1, y1, d):
3075 """
3076 Return the point on the line connecting (*x0*, *y0*) -- (*x1*, *y1*) whose
3077 distance from (*x0*, *y0*) is *d*.
3078 """
3079 dx, dy = x0 - x1, y0 - y1
3080 ff = d / (dx * dx + dy * dy) ** .5
3081 x2, y2 = x0 - ff * dx, y0 - ff * dy
3082  
3083 return x2, y2

3086 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
3087 class ArrowStyle(_Style):
3088 """
3089 `ArrowStyle` is a container class which defines several
3090 arrowstyle classes, which is used to create an arrow path along a
3091 given path. These are mainly used with `FancyArrowPatch`.
3092  
3093 An arrowstyle object can be either created as::
3094  
3095 ArrowStyle.Fancy(head_length=.4, head_width=.4, tail_width=.4)
3096  
3097 or::
3098  
3099 ArrowStyle("Fancy", head_length=.4, head_width=.4, tail_width=.4)
3100  
3101 or::
3102  
3103 ArrowStyle("Fancy, head_length=.4, head_width=.4, tail_width=.4")
3104  
3105 The following classes are defined
3106  
3107 %(ArrowStyle:table)s
3108  
3109 For an overview of the visual appearance, see
3110 :doc:`/gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/fancyarrow_demo`.
3111  
3112 An instance of any arrow style class is a callable object,
3113 whose call signature is::
3114  
3115 __call__(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth, aspect_ratio=1.)
3116  
3117 and it returns a tuple of a `.Path` instance and a boolean
3118 value. *path* is a `.Path` instance along which the arrow
3119 will be drawn. *mutation_size* and *aspect_ratio* have the same
3120 meaning as in `BoxStyle`. *linewidth* is a line width to be
3121 stroked. This is meant to be used to correct the location of the
3122 head so that it does not overshoot the destination point, but not all
3123 classes support it.
3124  
3125 Notes
3126 -----
3127 *angleA* and *angleB* specify the orientation of the bracket, as either a
3128 clockwise or counterclockwise angle depending on the arrow type. 0 degrees
3129 means perpendicular to the line connecting the arrow's head and tail.
3130  
3131 .. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/angles_on_bracket_arrows.py
3132 """
3133  
3134 _style_list = {}
3135  
3136 class _Base:
3137 """
3138 Arrow Transmuter Base class
3139  
3140 ArrowTransmuterBase and its derivatives are used to make a fancy
3141 arrow around a given path. The __call__ method returns a path
3142 (which will be used to create a PathPatch instance) and a boolean
3143 value indicating the path is open therefore is not fillable. This
3144 class is not an artist and actual drawing of the fancy arrow is
3145 done by the FancyArrowPatch class.
3146 """
3147  
3148 # The derived classes are required to be able to be initialized
3149 # w/o arguments, i.e., all its argument (except self) must have
3150 # the default values.
3151  
3152 @staticmethod
3153 def ensure_quadratic_bezier(path):
3154 """
3155 Some ArrowStyle classes only works with a simple quadratic
3156 Bézier curve (created with `.ConnectionStyle.Arc3` or
3157 `.ConnectionStyle.Angle3`). This static method checks if the
3158 provided path is a simple quadratic Bézier curve and returns its
3159 control points if true.
3160 """
3161 segments = list(path.iter_segments())
3162 if (len(segments) != 2 or segments[0][1] != Path.MOVETO or
3163 segments[1][1] != Path.CURVE3):
3164 raise ValueError(
3165 "'path' is not a valid quadratic Bezier curve")
3166 return [*segments[0][0], *segments[1][0]]
3167  
3168 def transmute(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth):
3169 """
3170 The transmute method is the very core of the ArrowStyle class and
3171 must be overridden in the subclasses. It receives the *path*
3172 object along which the arrow will be drawn, and the
3173 *mutation_size*, with which the arrow head etc. will be scaled.
3174 The *linewidth* may be used to adjust the path so that it does not
3175 pass beyond the given points. It returns a tuple of a `.Path`
3176 instance and a boolean. The boolean value indicate whether the
3177 path can be filled or not. The return value can also be a list of
3178 paths and list of booleans of the same length.
3179 """
3180 raise NotImplementedError('Derived must override')
3181  
3182 def __call__(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth,
3183 aspect_ratio=1.):
3184 """
3185 The __call__ method is a thin wrapper around the transmute method
3186 and takes care of the aspect ratio.
3187 """
3188  
3189 if aspect_ratio is not None:
3190 # Squeeze the given height by the aspect_ratio
3191 vertices = path.vertices / [1, aspect_ratio]
3192 path_shrunk = Path(vertices, path.codes)
3193 # call transmute method with squeezed height.
3194 path_mutated, fillable = self.transmute(path_shrunk,
3195 mutation_size,
3196 linewidth)
3197 if np.iterable(fillable):
3198 # Restore the height
3199 path_list = [Path(p.vertices * [1, aspect_ratio], p.codes)
3200 for p in path_mutated]
3201 return path_list, fillable
3202 else:
3203 return path_mutated, fillable
3204 else:
3205 return self.transmute(path, mutation_size, linewidth)
3206  
3207 class _Curve(_Base):
3208 """
3209 A simple arrow which will work with any path instance. The
3210 returned path is the concatenation of the original path, and at
3211 most two paths representing the arrow head or bracket at the start
3212 point and at the end point. The arrow heads can be either open
3213 or closed.
3214 """
3215  
3216 arrow = "-"
3217 fillbegin = fillend = False # Whether arrows are filled.
3218  
3219 def __init__(self, head_length=.4, head_width=.2, widthA=1., widthB=1.,
3220 lengthA=0.2, lengthB=0.2, angleA=0, angleB=0, scaleA=None,
3221 scaleB=None):
3222 """
3223 Parameters
3224 ----------
3225 head_length : float, default: 0.4
3226 Length of the arrow head, relative to *mutation_size*.
3227 head_width : float, default: 0.2
3228 Width of the arrow head, relative to *mutation_size*.
3229 widthA, widthB : float, default: 1.0
3230 Width of the bracket.
3231 lengthA, lengthB : float, default: 0.2
3232 Length of the bracket.
3233 angleA, angleB : float, default: 0
3234 Orientation of the bracket, as a counterclockwise angle.
3235 0 degrees means perpendicular to the line.
3236 scaleA, scaleB : float, default: *mutation_size*
3237 The scale of the brackets.
3238 """
3239  
3240 self.head_length, self.head_width = head_length, head_width
3241 self.widthA, self.widthB = widthA, widthB
3242 self.lengthA, self.lengthB = lengthA, lengthB
3243 self.angleA, self.angleB = angleA, angleB
3244 self.scaleA, self.scaleB = scaleA, scaleB
3245  
3246 self._beginarrow_head = False
3247 self._beginarrow_bracket = False
3248 self._endarrow_head = False
3249 self._endarrow_bracket = False
3250  
3251 if "-" not in self.arrow:
3252 raise ValueError("arrow must have the '-' between "
3253 "the two heads")
3254  
3255 beginarrow, endarrow = self.arrow.split("-", 1)
3256  
3257 if beginarrow == "<":
3258 self._beginarrow_head = True
3259 self._beginarrow_bracket = False
3260 elif beginarrow == "<|":
3261 self._beginarrow_head = True
3262 self._beginarrow_bracket = False
3263 self.fillbegin = True
3264 elif beginarrow in ("]", "|"):
3265 self._beginarrow_head = False
3266 self._beginarrow_bracket = True
3267  
3268 if endarrow == ">":
3269 self._endarrow_head = True
3270 self._endarrow_bracket = False
3271 elif endarrow == "|>":
3272 self._endarrow_head = True
3273 self._endarrow_bracket = False
3274 self.fillend = True
3275 elif endarrow in ("[", "|"):
3276 self._endarrow_head = False
3277 self._endarrow_bracket = True
3278  
3279 super().__init__()
3280  
3281 def _get_arrow_wedge(self, x0, y0, x1, y1,
3282 head_dist, cos_t, sin_t, linewidth):
3283 """
3284 Return the paths for arrow heads. Since arrow lines are
3285 drawn with capstyle=projected, The arrow goes beyond the
3286 desired point. This method also returns the amount of the path
3287 to be shrunken so that it does not overshoot.
3288 """
3289  
3290 # arrow from x0, y0 to x1, y1
3291 dx, dy = x0 - x1, y0 - y1
3292  
3293 cp_distance = np.hypot(dx, dy)
3294  
3295 # pad_projected : amount of pad to account the
3296 # overshooting of the projection of the wedge
3297 pad_projected = (.5 * linewidth / sin_t)
3298  
3299 # Account for division by zero
3300 if cp_distance == 0:
3301 cp_distance = 1
3302  
3303 # apply pad for projected edge
3304 ddx = pad_projected * dx / cp_distance
3305 ddy = pad_projected * dy / cp_distance
3306  
3307 # offset for arrow wedge
3308 dx = dx / cp_distance * head_dist
3309 dy = dy / cp_distance * head_dist
3310  
3311 dx1, dy1 = cos_t * dx + sin_t * dy, -sin_t * dx + cos_t * dy
3312 dx2, dy2 = cos_t * dx - sin_t * dy, sin_t * dx + cos_t * dy
3313  
3314 vertices_arrow = [(x1 + ddx + dx1, y1 + ddy + dy1),
3315 (x1 + ddx, y1 + ddy),
3316 (x1 + ddx + dx2, y1 + ddy + dy2)]
3317 codes_arrow = [Path.MOVETO,
3318 Path.LINETO,
3319 Path.LINETO]
3320  
3321 return vertices_arrow, codes_arrow, ddx, ddy
3322  
3323 def _get_bracket(self, x0, y0,
3324 x1, y1, width, length, angle):
3325  
3326 cos_t, sin_t = get_cos_sin(x1, y1, x0, y0)
3327  
3328 # arrow from x0, y0 to x1, y1
3329 from matplotlib.bezier import get_normal_points
3330 x1, y1, x2, y2 = get_normal_points(x0, y0, cos_t, sin_t, width)
3331  
3332 dx, dy = length * cos_t, length * sin_t
3333  
3334 vertices_arrow = [(x1 + dx, y1 + dy),
3335 (x1, y1),
3336 (x2, y2),
3337 (x2 + dx, y2 + dy)]
3338 codes_arrow = [Path.MOVETO,
3339 Path.LINETO,
3340 Path.LINETO,
3341 Path.LINETO]
3342  
3343 if angle:
3344 trans = transforms.Affine2D().rotate_deg_around(x0, y0, angle)
3345 vertices_arrow = trans.transform(vertices_arrow)
3346  
3347 return vertices_arrow, codes_arrow
3348  
3349 def transmute(self, path, mutation_size, linewidth):
3350 # docstring inherited
3351 if self._beginarrow_head or self._endarrow_head:
3352 head_length = self.head_length * mutation_size
3353 head_width = self.head_width * mutation_size
3354 head_dist = np.hypot(head_length, head_width)
3355 cos_t, sin_t = head_length / head_dist, head_width / head_dist
3356  
3357 scaleA = mutation_size if self.scaleA is None else self.scaleA
3358 scaleB = mutation_size if self.scaleB is None else self.scaleB
3359  
3360 # begin arrow
3361 x0, y0 = path.vertices[0]
3362 x1, y1 = path.vertices[1]
3363  
3364 # If there is no room for an arrow and a line, then skip the arrow
3365 has_begin_arrow = self._beginarrow_head and (x0, y0) != (x1, y1)
3366 verticesA, codesA, ddxA, ddyA = (
3367 self._get_arrow_wedge(x1, y1, x0, y0,
3368 head_dist, cos_t, sin_t, linewidth)
3369 if has_begin_arrow
3370 else ([], [], 0, 0)
3371 )
3372  
3373 # end arrow
3374 x2, y2 = path.vertices[-2]
3375 x3, y3 = path.vertices[-1]
3376  
3377 # If there is no room for an arrow and a line, then skip the arrow
3378 has_end_arrow = self._endarrow_head and (x2, y2) != (x3, y3)
3379 verticesB, codesB, ddxB, ddyB = (
3380 self._get_arrow_wedge(x2, y2, x3, y3,
3381 head_dist, cos_t, sin_t, linewidth)
3382 if has_end_arrow
3383 else ([], [], 0, 0)
3384 )
3385  
3386 # This simple code will not work if ddx, ddy is greater than the
3387 # separation between vertices.
3388 paths = [Path(np.concatenate([[(x0 + ddxA, y0 + ddyA)],
3389 path.vertices[1:-1],
3390 [(x3 + ddxB, y3 + ddyB)]]),
3391 path.codes)]
3392 fills = [False]
3393  
3394 if has_begin_arrow:
3395 if self.fillbegin:
3396 paths.append(
3397 Path([*verticesA, (0, 0)], [*codesA, Path.CLOSEPOLY]))
3398 fills.append(True)
3399 else:
3400 paths.append(Path(verticesA, codesA))
3401 fills.append(False)
3402 elif self._beginarrow_bracket:
3403 x0, y0 = path.vertices[0]
3404 x1, y1 = path.vertices[1]
3405 verticesA, codesA = self._get_bracket(x0, y0, x1, y1,
3406 self.widthA * scaleA,
3407 self.lengthA * scaleA,
3408 self.angleA)
3409  
3410 paths.append(Path(verticesA, codesA))
3411 fills.append(False)
3412  
3413 if has_end_arrow:
3414 if self.fillend:
3415 fills.append(True)
3416 paths.append(
3417 Path([*verticesB, (0, 0)], [*codesB, Path.CLOSEPOLY]))
3418 else:
3419 fills.append(False)
3420 paths.append(Path(verticesB, codesB))
3421 elif self._endarrow_bracket:
3422 x0, y0 = path.vertices[-1]
3423 x1, y1 = path.vertices[-2]
3424 verticesB, codesB = self._get_bracket(x0, y0, x1, y1,
3425 self.widthB * scaleB,
3426 self.lengthB * scaleB,
3427 self.angleB)
3428  
3429 paths.append(Path(verticesB, codesB))
3430 fills.append(False)
3431  
3432 return paths, fills

4054 class FancyArrowPatch(Patch):
4055 """
4056 A fancy arrow patch.
4057  
4058 It draws an arrow using the `ArrowStyle`. It is primarily used by the
  • E501 Line too long (82 > 79 characters)
4059 `~.axes.Axes.annotate` method. For most purposes, use the annotate method for
4060 drawing arrows.
4061  
4062 The head and tail positions are fixed at the specified start and end points
4063 of the arrow, but the size and shape (in display coordinates) of the arrow
4064 does not change when the axis is moved or zoomed.
4065 """
4066 _edge_default = True
4067  
4068 def __str__(self):
4069 if self._posA_posB is not None:
4070 (x1, y1), (x2, y2) = self._posA_posB
4071 return f"{type(self).__name__}(({x1:g}, {y1:g})->({x2:g}, {y2:g}))"
4072 else:
4073 return f"{type(self).__name__}({self._path_original})"
4074  
4075 @_docstring.dedent_interpd
4076 def __init__(self, posA=None, posB=None, *,
4077 path=None, arrowstyle="simple", connectionstyle="arc3",
4078 patchA=None, patchB=None, shrinkA=2, shrinkB=2,
4079 mutation_scale=1, mutation_aspect=1, **kwargs):
4080 """
4081 There are two ways for defining an arrow:
4082  
4083 - If *posA* and *posB* are given, a path connecting two points is
4084 created according to *connectionstyle*. The path will be
4085 clipped with *patchA* and *patchB* and further shrunken by
4086 *shrinkA* and *shrinkB*. An arrow is drawn along this
4087 resulting path using the *arrowstyle* parameter.
4088  
4089 - Alternatively if *path* is provided, an arrow is drawn along this
4090 path and *patchA*, *patchB*, *shrinkA*, and *shrinkB* are ignored.
4091  
4092 Parameters
4093 ----------
4094 posA, posB : (float, float), default: None
4095 (x, y) coordinates of arrow tail and arrow head respectively.
4096  
4097 path : `~matplotlib.path.Path`, default: None
4098 If provided, an arrow is drawn along this path and *patchA*,
4099 *patchB*, *shrinkA*, and *shrinkB* are ignored.
4100  
4101 arrowstyle : str or `.ArrowStyle`, default: 'simple'
4102 The `.ArrowStyle` with which the fancy arrow is drawn. If a
4103 string, it should be one of the available arrowstyle names, with
4104 optional comma-separated attributes. The optional attributes are
4105 meant to be scaled with the *mutation_scale*. The following arrow
4106 styles are available:
4107  
4108 %(ArrowStyle:table)s
4109  
4110 connectionstyle : str or `.ConnectionStyle` or None, optional, \
4111 default: 'arc3'
4112 The `.ConnectionStyle` with which *posA* and *posB* are connected.
4113 If a string, it should be one of the available connectionstyle
4114 names, with optional comma-separated attributes. The following
4115 connection styles are available:
4116  
4117 %(ConnectionStyle:table)s
4118  
4119 patchA, patchB : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch`, default: None
4120 Head and tail patches, respectively.
4121  
4122 shrinkA, shrinkB : float, default: 2
4123 Shrinking factor of the tail and head of the arrow respectively.
4124  
4125 mutation_scale : float, default: 1
4126 Value with which attributes of *arrowstyle* (e.g., *head_length*)
4127 will be scaled.
4128  
4129 mutation_aspect : None or float, default: None
4130 The height of the rectangle will be squeezed by this value before
4131 the mutation and the mutated box will be stretched by the inverse
4132 of it.
4133  
4134 Other Parameters
4135 ----------------
4136 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties, optional
4137 Here is a list of available `.Patch` properties:
4138  
4139 %(Patch:kwdoc)s
4140  
4141 In contrast to other patches, the default ``capstyle`` and
4142 ``joinstyle`` for `FancyArrowPatch` are set to ``"round"``.
4143 """
4144 # Traditionally, the cap- and joinstyle for FancyArrowPatch are round
4145 kwargs.setdefault("joinstyle", JoinStyle.round)
4146 kwargs.setdefault("capstyle", CapStyle.round)
4147  
4148 super().__init__(**kwargs)
4149  
4150 if posA is not None and posB is not None and path is None:
4151 self._posA_posB = [posA, posB]
4152  
4153 if connectionstyle is None:
4154 connectionstyle = "arc3"
4155 self.set_connectionstyle(connectionstyle)
4156  
4157 elif posA is None and posB is None and path is not None:
4158 self._posA_posB = None
4159 else:
4160 raise ValueError("Either posA and posB, or path need to provided")
4161  
4162 self.patchA = patchA
4163 self.patchB = patchB
4164 self.shrinkA = shrinkA
4165 self.shrinkB = shrinkB
4166  
4167 self._path_original = path
4168  
4169 self.set_arrowstyle(arrowstyle)
4170  
4171 self._mutation_scale = mutation_scale
4172 self._mutation_aspect = mutation_aspect
4173  
4174 self._dpi_cor = 1.0
4175  
4176 def set_positions(self, posA, posB):
4177 """
4178 Set the start and end positions of the connecting path.
4179  
4180 Parameters
4181 ----------
4182 posA, posB : None, tuple
4183 (x, y) coordinates of arrow tail and arrow head respectively. If
4184 `None` use current value.
4185 """
4186 if posA is not None:
4187 self._posA_posB[0] = posA
4188 if posB is not None:
4189 self._posA_posB[1] = posB
4190 self.stale = True
4191
